page.title: 14St. Etheldreda's church
page.content: A church has stood on the site for well over{700 years}and there are several parts still visible from those early days. There are traces of a Norman doorway in the south wall of the chancel. The nave and the aisles are both under one big roof but the chancel is rather narrower. The chancel arch also dates from the Norman days but when they built it they used some bricks and tiles from an early Roman building. The Roman villa had stood in Church Meadow. Lots of wall paintings were painted over during the days of Oliver Cromwell but it may be possible to uncover them again soon. There is a big dug out chest in the church which was once used to collect 'St.Peter's Pence' which was money sent to St.Peter's cathedral in Rome.
